ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An extension of single-variable calculus into multivariable and vector calculus. Useful for physics.
How to take material and teach myself.
Refreshed knowledge of previous calculus topics, and developed multivariable calculus knowledge.
I gained a strong foundation in multivariable calculus that I believe will be helpful in future applications.
The course leaves you with an in-depth understanding of the concepts covered.
I developed the ability to think critically in new ways, especially when it comes to conceptualizing Three-Dimensional shapes and figures.
I learned multivariable calculus.
I learned how to dive deeper and fully understand the concepts instead of just memorizing them.

This class taught me how to develop a toolbox of working theorems and problem solving techniques and how to apply each theorem or technique to a problem to best solve it. This skill, on top of the knowledge of three dimensional surfaces, vector calculus, and calculus of functions of several variables, will definitely aid my mathematical thinking and problem-solving in math courses down the road.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I suppose each section is taught differently, but the one taught by Dr Su Ji had in-class worksheets which helped tremendously. The structure of the class was less lecture and more problem solving which I found to be very effective in solidifying understanding of concepts. I don't think the pre-class videos were especially necessary, since the classes covered basically the same thing. However, I do admit that watching the pre-class videos would make learning from the class itself a lot easier. It's like going through the same content twice.

Strengths: Well organized, daily videos and quizzes super helpful.
Weaknesses: fast paced, but understandable due to lack of class days.

This course needs to do more practice problems during class. i felt as if i taught myself majority of the math in the class and did not fully comprehend the material till it was time to take exams. It was just really fast paced and the videos were basically the classes themselves.
It starts off very quick, but the rigor of the course becomes more comfortable as the course goes on.
The material moves quite fast, but the content is very interesting.
The psets were difficult and took time and assistance to finish. However, they left you prepared for the tests. Additionally, support from peer tutors and professors was readily available.

This could did a wonderful job of facilitating an understanding of multivariable calculus. I wish the tracing styles were more similar throughout the course, but my professor did a wonderful job of ensuring everyone knew all the information.

The flipped classroom structure of the course is great. Learning the concepts through videos that I can pause and rewatch is really helpful, and then being able to apply those concepts in class on practice problems is also helpful.

Strengths:
- The guided notes and videos on Canvas were really useful for understanding the material.

Weaknesses:
- The PSets are extremely long. While they're useful for learning the material, they felt a little pointless overall because of how little they matter for the overall grade.
I wish there were more resources to study the concepts further. I do appreciate the many hours of peer tutoring available.

This class is organized well and the teachers for each section are more than willing to help you work through difficult concepts. Since this class has such high enrollment, more TA office hours, and more specificity in professor office hours, would help students ask questions about the material to gain a better understanding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's very specific to calculus (as the name of the class suggests), and for a physics major this was quite relevant, although I would not say absolutely necessary?
Yes; this is a good class to continue to develop calculus knowledge. It is well organized, and I learned a lot through lectures, videos, and problem sets.

I would recommend this course to students who are looking for a challenge. If they are not prepared for the challenge then I would not take this course. It requires alot of effort and time outside of the classroom.
Yes, I think the topics learned in this course are very interesting, and it should be taken for anyone who needs to take it.
Yes, it challenges you intellectually and has many applications.
Yes, if its required or you are interested in math.
I would recommend this course to another student- it is amazing how your spatial conceptualization and ability to think in different planes is expanded!
Yes, if you already have a good understanding of calculus.
I would recommend this course to students who need to take multivariable calculus for their major as a prerequisite.
I would recommend only for students that need the course for their major. Otherwise, it is a big courseload to take on.

I would recommend this course. Multivariable calculus is applicable in so many situations and in so many professions, and this course gives a very good overview of the essential topics. The workload can get tough, but it is usually manageable, and there are ways to get help if you're stuck on a problem set or struggling with a concept.
